section.title: Overview

para.emphasis: This section answers the question “What is this feature?”

section.para: [Enter an overview of the feature as you would explain it to a technical writer — what is this feature all about?
[Provide essential background information that users must understand before they can complete the tasks successfully.]

section.title: Reason

para.emphasis: This section answers the question “Why do I need this feature?”

section.para: [A feature is usually implemented to solve a business issue. Explain this issue to the user here.]

section.title: Tasks

para.emphasis: This section answers the question “How do I use this feature?”

section.para: [Provide a detailed procedure for running the feature. The procedure should have multiple steps on how to achieve the goal. Include screenshots as needed. Make sure you are not including any confidential data in the screenshots.
[Tasks are the main building blocks for task-oriented user documentation. They provide step-by-step instructions that lets the user perform a task.]

section.title: Reference information
section.para: [A reference topic documents programming constructs or facts about a product. Examples of reference information are: language elements, class descriptions, commands, functions, statements, protocols, types, declarators, operands, and API information.
[Reference information provides quick access to facts, but no explanation of concepts or procedures. Assume that users already understand the base technology.
[Reference information is usually included in a table to allow the user to scan through the information quickly and easily.]
